Table 4 Sample Weight percent of each element (%) Ni/Si (atomic ratio) Ni Si Na O 32% NiO-SiO2 (P) 20.1 28.1 0.1 51.7 0.3 49% NiO-SiO2 (P) 38.4 15.2 0.1 46.3 1.2 66% NiO-SiO2 (P) 41.1 9.9 0 49.0 2.0 32% Ni/SiO2 (P) 17.4 35.3 0.5 46.8 0.2 49% Ni/SiO2 (P) 21.2 27.7 0.4 50.7 0.4 66% Ni/SiO2 (P) 29.5 22.9 0 47.6 0.6 Active Ni/SiO2 catalysts with high Ni content for benzene hydrogenation and CO methanation Thien An Le Jong Kyu Kang Eun Duck Park ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering and Department of Energy Systems Research, Ajou University, 206 Worldcup-ro Yeongtong-gu, Suwon, 16499, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering and Department of Energy Systems Research Ajou University 206 Worldcup-ro Yeongtong-gu Suwon 16499 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Ni/SiO2 catalysts with high Ni content were prepared from aqueous Ni(NO3)2 solutions by the precipitation method using Na2SiO3 as a silica precursor and precipitant. This is a simple but efficient method to prepare well-dispersed NiO on silica, which can be further transformed to Ni/SiO2 through an additional reduction process. Various techniques such as nitrogen physisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR), hydrogen chemisorption, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) were employed to characterize the catalysts. The prepared catalysts were applied to two model reactions, benzene hydrogenation and CO methanation. The catalyst showed significantly enhanced performance for these reactions compared to core-shell Ni@SiO2 catalysts and conventional Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by wet impregnation. Keywords Ni/SiO2 Na2SiO3 Catalyst preparation Hydrogenation CO methanation Benzene Hydrogenation 1 Introduction Ni-based catalysts are typically supported metal catalysts with a large market size due to their relatively high catalytic activity and economic efficiency [1–3]. Various supports have been investigated to enhance catalytic activity and improve the stability of supported Ni catalysts [2–22]. Among them, SiO2 is the most widely used support for Ni-based catalysts because it offers the advantages of mechanical strength, high specific surface area, strong interaction with the active catalyst components, thereby facilitating high dispersion of metal and good sintering resistance, which result in excellent catalytic performance [5,7,9,11,12,18,20,3–22]. All catalytic reactions over supported metal catalysts are strongly dependent on metal dispersion. For structure-insensitive reactions, the intrinsic catalytic activity is proportional to the catalytically active surface area (CASA), which can be determined by measuring the metal dispersion and metal content [1,4,23]. Apart from high-temperature reactions such as steam reformation of hydrocarbons, supported metal catalysts with high metal content are frequently used for low-temperature reactions which are mostly kinetically controlled [1,10,23]. The wet impregnation (WI) method is a well-known and commercially available technique for the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts. However, the maximum metal content that can be achieved while preserving high metal dispersion is limited in conventional WI [8,12,18]. Several novel preparation methods that guarantee high metal dispersion with high metal content have been reported [2,3,5,7,8,12,15,18,21,23–27], including a core-shell-type catalyst where the active metal is coated with mesoporous metal oxide layers [5,7,12,21,27]. Ni@SiO2 with core-shell structure exhibits high methanation activity, high sintering resistance due to the protection of the robust silica shell, and excellent coke resistance by restricting the formation of coke [27–29]. However, this method requires several steps that involve long preparation times, limiting its economic feasibility for mass production. Therefore, novel and simple catalyst preparation methods are required to increase metal dispersion with high metal content. The precipitation method is a well-known method that can be used to prepare heterogeneous catalysts with a homogeneous component distribution, relatively low reaction temperature, fine and uniform particle size with weakly agglomerated particles, and low cost [24]. Na2SiO3 is a low-cost silica precursor and possible candidate as a precipitant. Conventional synthesis procedures for producing SiO2 from sodium silicate are performed under acidic conditions [30–32], which usually results in agglomeration. The alkaline conditions required to produce non-agglomerated SiO2 particles have been less studied [33]. The combination of Ni(OH)2 during the first precipitation step with different pH media to control the size and structure [34] as well as the formation of SiO2 from Na2SiO3 are expected to increase the dispersion of Ni species and result in higher catalytic activity. In this study, we prepared NiO-SiO2 samples from an aqueous acidic Ni precursor solution via precipitation using Na2SiO3 as a precipitant and silica precursor. These samples were reduced to prepare Ni/SiO2 catalysts and then applied to model reactions including benzene hydrogenation and CO methanation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Ni/SiO2 catalysts were prepared in two steps by precipitation using Na2SiO3 as the precursor for SiO2, as described in Scheme 1 . The detailed parameters in the catalyst preparation are listed in Table 1 . 2.1.1 Synthesis of nickel hydroxide A calculated amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (Junsei Chemical Co., Ltd.) was dissolved in the corresponding amount of deionized (DI) water to prepare a 0.1 M nickel nitrate solution. Subsequently, a 0.2 M Na2CO3 solution was prepared from Na2CO3 (Daejung Chemicals & Metals Co., Ltd.) and added dropwise to the nickel nitrate solution until reaching the desired intermediate pH under vigorous stirring at ambient temperature. The nickel hydroxide suspension was stabilized for 1 h under stirring for the next step. 2.1.2 Synthesis of the Ni/SiO2 catalysts First, a 0.25 M Na2SiO3 solution was prepared by dissolving 142 g of Na2SiO3·9H2O (Sigma Aldrich Co.) in 2 L of DI water under vigorous stirring. A calculated amount of Na2SiO3 solution was added dropwise to the nickel hydroxide suspension to prepare the NiO-SiO2 sample with a specific Ni content. The final suspension was aged at room temperature for 6 h under stirring, then collected after filtration and washed with DI water several times. The obtained cake was dried in a vacuum oven at 110 °C for 12 h and subsequently calcined in air at 500 °C for 3 h. The calcined samples were further reduced under a hydrogen stream at 500 °C for 1 h to prepare the Ni/SiO2 catalysts. The sample prepared by the precipitation method and calcined in air at 500 ℃ was denoted as NiO-SiO2 (P), and was further reduced under a hydrogen stream at 500 ℃ (designated as Ni/SiO2 (P)). For comparison, a 55 wt% Ni@SiO2 catalyst with a core-shell structure [12] and 33 wt% Ni/SiO2 catalyst prepared via WI [13], which was denoted as Ni/SiO2 (WI), were also evaluated for their model reaction activity. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The physical properties of the samples, including BET surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter, were measured via N2 physisorption analysis at −196 °C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. All samples were degassed under vacuum for 6 h at 200 ℃ prior to analysis. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses of the samples were conducted using a Rigaku D/Max instrument equipped with a Cu Kα source. The primary crystallite size of Ni in the samples was determined using the Scherrer equation [35]: (1) L = 0.9 λ K α 1 β 2 θ c o s θ m a x where L is the average particle size, β 2 θ is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the peak, λ K α 1 is the wavelength of the X-ray radiation (0.15406 nm), and θ m a x is the angular position of the (111) peak maximum of NiO or the (111) peak maximum of Ni. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed using a K-alpha spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, USA) equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV). The C1 s peak at 285 eV was used as a reference for all binding energies. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were obtained using Tecnai G2 TEM (FEI) operating at 200 kV and equipped with an EDS detector. The sample was finely ground and dispersed ultrasonically in ethanol before deposition on a Cu grid covered by a perforated carbon film. Temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) was performed using a Micromeritics 2910 Autochem instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For this step, 0.10 g of the sample was loaded and contacted with 10 mol% H2/Ar at a flow rate of 30 mL/min at 40–900 ℃. The CASA and Ni dispersion for each catalyst were determined via H2 chemisorption using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The detailed procedure has been described in a previous study [9]. Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) was performed using a Thermo Scientific iCAP 6500 instrument to determine the metal content of each sample, which are listed in Table S1. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation 2.3.1 Benzene hydrogenation First, 0.1 g of reduced catalyst was passivated with a feed gas composed of 2 mol% O2 balanced in He at a flow rate of 60 mL/min at 30 °C for 3 h. Benzene hydrogenation was performed in an autoclave reactor at 80 ℃ for 4 h at 20 bar of hydrogen. The products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (YL Instrument 6100GC) equipped with a capillary SUPELCO WAX10 column and flame ionization detector (FID). The benzene conversion ( X B ) and turnover frequency ( T O F ) were calculated according to the following equations: (2) X B % = n B i n - n B o u t n B i n × 100 (3) T O F = n B i n - n B o u t n N i × t i m e ( s ) where n B i n , n B o u t , and n N i are the number of moles of benzene before reaction, number of moles of benzene in the collected liquid after reaction, and number of moles of active Ni determined by H2 chemisorption, respectively. 2.3.2 CO methanation CO methanation was performed as mentioned in our previous works [8,9]. The detailed procedure is described in the supplementary information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts Fig. 1 shows the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the prepared catalysts. All isotherms corresponded to the type-IV isotherm according to IUPAC classification, which is characteristic of mesoporous materials [36]. A well-defined hysteresis (H2 type) was observed for all samples, indicating the presence of disordered pores [36]. The corresponding physical properties of the prepared catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . The 32% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalyst exhibited the largest BET surface area and smallest pore volume among the Ni/SiO2 (P) samples since the largest amount of Na2SiO3 was used for this sample. The BET surface area of all Ni/SiO2 (P) samples was relatively high, indicating that the silica pores were well-developed during the precipitation step. A rather narrow pore distribution determined from the desorption branch was observed for all Ni/SiO2 (P) samples (Fig. 1B) and the average pore size increased with increasing Ni content (Table 2). XRD analyses were performed to characterize the bulk crystalline structure of the samples. As shown in Fig. 2 A, the XRD patterns of the calcined samples reveal that NiO (JCPDS 47–1049) was the main bulk structure for all samples, except for that of 32% NiO-SiO2 (P) where weak XRD peaks were observed at 34.1 and 61.1° corresponding to the nickel phyllosilicate phase Ni3Si2O5(OH)4 (JCPDS 49–1859). The crystalline phase of nickel phyllosilicate was not fully developed as revealed by very weak XRD peaks corresponding to nickel phyllosilicate. After calcination at 500 °C, the XRD peak at 2θ = 37.2° indexed to the (111) face of the cubic NiO phase (JCPDS 47–1049) was observed. This XRD peak overlapped to the XRD peak at 2θ = 35° due to the nickel phyllosilicate, resulting in the rather broad XRD peak. Besides, due to the loss of hydroxyl groups and the decrease in the inter-lamellar spacing, the XRD peak at 2θ = 25° corresponding to (004) plane of Ni3Si2O5(OH)4 might be very weak. This XRD peak cannot be distinguished in the presence of very broad XRD peak due to the amorphous SiO2. The crystallite size of NiO in each sample was calculated according to the Scherrer equation and the results are listed in Table 3 . The crystallite sizes of NiO in NiO@SiO2 and NiO/SiO2 (WI) were 5 and 20 nm, respectively. This indicates that the WI method does not provide small NiO particles when the Ni content is high. For the NiO-SiO2 (P) samples, the XRD peak corresponding to NiO was too weak to calculate crystallite size for 32% NiO-SiO2 (P) and the crystallite size of NiO was 6 nm for the 49% NiO-SiO2 (P) and 66% NiO-SiO2 (P) samples. It is quite remarkable that very small NiO particles were obtained for the NiO-SiO2 (P) samples even at high Ni content without using a capping agent, which is required for NiO@SiO2. After reduction, NiO in the calcined samples was reduced to metallic Ni (JCPDS 04-0850), as shown in Fig. 2B. The crystallite sizes of Ni in Ni@SiO2 and NiO/SiO2 (WI) were 13 and 19 nm, respectively. Compared to the calcined samples, the crystallite size of Ni in Ni@SiO2 increased significantly, but little change was observed in the crystallite size of Ni in Ni/SiO2 (WI) after reduction. For the Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts, the crystallite size of Ni was much smaller than those of Ni@SiO2 and NiO/SiO2 (WI), although the crystallite size of Ni increased with increasing Ni content for the Ni@SiO2 catalysts (Table 3). The XRD patterns of the 66% NiO-SiO2 (P) samples at each preparation step were obtained and compared in Fig. S1. The presence of a nickel phyllosilicate phase was confirmed for the dried sample, but collapsed during the calcination step. However, this nickel phyllosilicate phase remained in the 32% NiO-SiO2 (P) sample even after calcination at 500 °C (Fig. 1A), indicating that the structural stability of the nickel phyllosilicate phase could be affected by the Ni/Si ratio. As Khan et al. [34] reported, the pH value during precipitation is a key factor controlling both the crystal structure and morphology of the resulting Ni(OH)2; a high pH of 10.5–11.0 is favorable for β-Ni(OH)2 formation, while the α-Ni(OH)2 structure is favored at a lower pH of 8.5–9.5. In this study, the pH was controlled by Na2CO3 solution during the first step of Ni(OH)2 preparation and the final pH was determined by the amount of Na2SiO3. Higher final pH was favorable for improving the stability of the nickel phyllosilicate structure. Fig. 3 shows the HRTEM images of the 66% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalyst. Uniform Ni particles with an average diameter of 12 nm were well-dispersed on the SiO2. A representative scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) dark field image and the corresponding elemental maps show that Ni, Si, and O were well-distributed in the sample. Similar results were obtained from the STEM analyses of the 49% Ni/SiO2 (P) and 32% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts, as presented in Figs. S2 and S3, respectively. The average particle sizes of Ni in the 49% Ni/SiO2 (P) and 32% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts were 5 and 4 nm, respectively. As shown in Table 3, the average particle size of Ni, as determined from the HRTEM images, was similar to the crystallite size of Ni calculated by the Scherrer equation for each catalyst. The Ni dispersion and CASA values of all catalysts were determined by H2 chemisorption and are summarized in Table 3. Ni dispersion and CASA were closely correlated to Ni size in each sample. The Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts exhibited much higher Ni dispersion and larger CASA than those of the Ni/SiO2 (WI) and Ni@SiO2 catalysts. Ni dispersion decreased with increasing Ni content and the CASA was positively associated with Ni dispersion for the Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts. The 32% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalyst showed the highest Ni dispersion and largest CASA among the Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts. The reducibility of the NiO species for the calcined samples was probed by H2-TPR. As shown in Fig. 4 , two reduction peaks were observed in the H2-TPR profiles. The low-temperature TPR peaks from 200 to 420 °C can be ascribed to the bulk NiO exhibiting a weak interaction with the support and high-temperature TPR peaks at 450–650 °C are due to NiO species incorporating strongly with the support [13]. For the NiO-SiO2 (P) samples, the high-temperature TPR peak weakened, but the low-temperature TPR peak strengthened with increasing Ni content. This implies a strong interaction between the NiO and SiO2, resulting in the low degree of reduction for the NiO-SiO2 (P) samples with low Ni content. Combining the XRD and H2-TPR data, it is clear that the high-temperature reduction peak is closely related to the reduction of Ni2+ species in the nickel phyllosilicate phase. Because the fraction of the high-temperature TPR peak increased with decreasing Ni content for the NiO-SiO2 (P) samples, the reduction degree of NiO is also correlated with Ni content (Table 3). NiO/SiO2 (WI) exhibited a rather broad TPR peak between 260 and 560 °C with a small shoulder at 510 °C, which can be ascribed to the reduction of bulk NiO to Ni species. The NiO@SiO2 sample showed a TPR peak at a higher temperature than that of NiO/SiO2 (WI), indicating that the former contained stronger interactions between NiO and SiO2 than the latter. To further understand the chemical state of each component and change in the surface composition during the reduction process, XPS spectra of each component for the calcined NiO-SiO2 (P) and reduced Ni/SiO2 (P) samples were obtained (Fig. S4). For the calcined 49% NiO-SiO2 (P) and 66% NiO-SiO2 (P) samples, a single peak at 853.0 eV (Ni2+2p3/2) was observed arising from the NiO phase and the other peak at 854.5 eV (Ni2+2p3/2) corresponded to Ni2+ in nickel phyllosilicate phase [37]. On the other hand, only a single peak, ascribed to the Ni2+ species in nickel phyllosilicate, was obtained for the calcined 32% NiO-SiO2 (P) sample. This indicates that the nickel phyllosilicate phase was predominantly formed even after calcination in air at 500 °C. From the XPS analysis in Fig. S5, the reduced Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts exhibited Ni 2p3/2 peaks at 851.6 and 855.3 eV, corresponding to Ni metal and Ni2+ interacting with Si species [26]. All reducible species of the NiO-SiO2 (P) catalysts could not be reduced at 500 °C, as observed from the H2-TPR results. The strong interactions between the NiO and SiO2 likely retained the Ni2+ species in the reduced catalysts. Based on the H2-TPR and XPS data, the Ni2+ species in the reduced catalysts can mainly be ascribed to Ni2+ in the nickel phyllosilicate phase. The binding energy peak of Si 2p at 102.5 eV was attributed to the SiO2. The surface concentration of Ni species determined by XPS analysis appears to be less than that of bulk concentration of Ni measured by ICP-AES technique. This indicates that some of surface Ni species are covered with SiO2 and Ni3Si2O5(OH)4. 3.2 Benzene hydrogenation Benzene hydrogenation was chosen as a model reaction to compare the activity among the prepared Ni-based catalysts. Under these reaction conditions, cyclohexane was the only product. As shown in Fig. 5 , the 33% Ni/SiO2 (WI) catalyst with the lowest CASA exhibited the lowest benzene conversion among the tested SiO2-supported Ni catalysts. The 55% Ni@SiO2 catalyst showed a better benzene conversion than the 33% Ni/SiO2 (WI) catalyst because the former catalyst has a larger CASA than the latter one. However, this catalyst was inferior to the Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts for this reaction. The Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts were superior to the 33% Ni/SiO2 (WI) catalyst because they exhibited larger CASA. The catalytic activity was represented as the benzene conversion and was shown to be proportional to the CASA. This is in agreement with previous reports [6,10,22]. The turnover frequency (TOF) at 80 °C for benzene hydrogenation over 33% Ni/SiO2 (WI) was 9.6 × 10−3 s-1, consistent with the previous study by Li et al. [17] who reported that the TOF for this reaction at 100 °C over 11.5% Raney Ni was 8.4 × 10−3 s-1. 3.3 CO methanation CO methanation was performed over the prepared Ni-based catalysts, and the CO conversions at different reaction temperatures are displayed in Fig. 6 . Among the supported Ni catalysts with similar Ni content, the activity for CO methanation was closely related to Ni dispersion and CASA. The 32% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalyst was more active than the 33% Ni/SiO2 (WI) catalyst and 49% Ni/SiO2 (P) was superior to 55% Ni@SiO2. It should be noted that the 32% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalyst showed the lowest performance for CO methanation among the Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts, although it exhibited the highest Ni dispersion and largest CASA. The effect of the surface hydroxyl species retained in the nickel phyllosilicate structure in the catalyst is likely the cause of these results. This nickel phyllosilicate structure is stable on the 32% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalyst even after calcination at 500 °C and was reported to suppress methane formation [37]. The 49% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalyst with CASA of 50 m2/gcat. showed improved CO methanation activity compared to that of 32% Ni/SiO2 (P) with CASA of 57 m2/gcat. The former has a much smaller fraction of nickel phyllosilicate phase than the latter. The Ni nanoparticle size also played an essential role by affecting CO dissociation in the CO methanation mechanism [38]. The Ni size range of approximately 10–20 nm with more flat surfaces was reported to be beneficial for the dissociation and hydrogenation of highly concentrated CO [20,39]. As a CO methanation catalyst, the 66% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalyst showed advantages in terms of its Ni particles size (average of 11 nm), high reducibility, relatively high CASA (36 m2/gcat.), and small fraction of nickel phyllosilicate phase. These factors contributed to the high catalytic activity for CO methanation. Another reason for the high activity is the absence of Na on the catalyst surface. As shown in Table 4 , the Na content on the surface of the Ni/SiO2 (P) samples decreased with increasing Ni content. This is directly related to the amount of Na2SiO3 used during catalyst preparation. A negative effect of Na was reported for CO methanation [13]. No detectable amount of Na was observed on the surface of the 66% Ni/SiO2 (P) catalyst, which can explain why this catalyst is more active than the other Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts with larger CASAs. During CO methanation, methane was the predominant product at all reaction temperatures (Fig. S6). Ethane and propane were also detected as byproducts with small yields up to 2% for C2H6 and 0.5% for C3H8. Notably, the nickel phyllosilicate structure in 32% Ni/SiO2 (P) affected the product selectivity, as a small amount of C2H6 was obtained without C3+ products. The −OH group in the nickel phyllosilicate structure changed the CO adsorption behavior, preventing CO dissociation and methanation, as well as suppressing hydrocarbon formation, as described in previous studies [40,41]. The catalytic stability test for CO methanation was performed over 66% Ni/SiO2 (P) at 180 ℃. In Fig. S7, the initial CO conversion was maintained for 24 h. The crystal structure was confirmed not to be changed by XRD analysis (Fig. S8). There was no detectable XRD signal due to crystalline carbon (graphite and whisker carbon) and NiO. No apparent morphological change was observed for the spent catalyst (Fig. S9). 4 Conclusions NiO-SiO2 (P) samples with small NiO particles and high Ni content were prepared from an aqueous Ni(NO3)2 solution by adding Na2CO3 to adjust the pH and a Na2SiO3 solution was subsequently added to control the Ni content. These samples were reduced to Ni/SiO2 (P) catalysts with high Ni content while preserving high Ni dispersion. These catalysts generally exhibited higher Ni dispersion, CASA, and activity for benzene hydrogenation and CO methanation compared with the Ni/SiO2 catalyst prepared via WI or a core-shell Ni@SiO2 catalyst with similar Ni content. The catalytic activity for benzene hydrogenation was directly related to the CASA. On the other hand, the catalytic activity for CO methanation was dependent on the CASA, nickel phyllosilicate phase, and residual Na on the catalyst surface. Acknowledgment This work was supported by the Human Resources Program in Energy Technology (No. 20154010200820) of the Korea Institute of Energy Technology Evaluation and Planning (KETEP), which was granted financial resources from the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy of the Republic of Korea. This work was also supported by the C1 Gas Refinery Program through the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) funded by the Ministry of Science and ICT (2015M3D3A1A01064899). coredata.dc:description: Ni/SiO2 catalysts with high Ni content were prepared from aqueous Ni(NO3)2 solutions by the precipitation method using Na2SiO3 as a silica precursor and precipitant. This is a simple but efficient method to prepare well-dispersed NiO on silica, which can be further transformed to Ni/SiO2 through an additional reduction process. Various techniques such as nitrogen physisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR), hydrogen chemisorption, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) were employed to characterize the catalysts. The prepared catalysts were applied to two model reactions, benzene hydrogenation and CO methanation. The catalyst showed significantly enhanced performance for these reactions compared to core-shell Ni@SiO2 catalysts and conventional Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by wet impregnation.
coredata.dc:title: Active Ni/SiO2 catalysts with high Ni content for benzene hydrogenation and CO methanation
